hedline.hl1: An Airport Security Game That Rivals the Real Thing

abstract.p: On the Road column discusses Airport Security online flash video game made by Persuasive Games; user plays role of airport security agent screening passengers; drawing (M)

block.p: MANY months ago, my wife got into Sudoku, which I assumed was a Japanese noodle dish when I first heard the word. She tried to explain it, but as my eyes glazed over she wisely gave up.

MANY months ago, my wife got into Sudoku, which I assumed was a Japanese noodle dish when I first heard the word. She tried to explain it, but as my eyes glazed over she wisely gave up.
So I consulted Wikipedia, which informed me that Sudoku is a ''logic-based placement puzzle'' involving ''a type of Latin square with an additional constraint on the content of individual regions.''

Well, nearly everybody knows that -- or seems to if you look at what's engrossing that passenger in the seat next to you or in the departure lounge. Some airlines even give out free Sudoku puzzle books.
But Sudoku remains beyond me. If asked to define a Latin square, the best answer I would come up with is ''Xavier Cugat.''

Luckily, though, I have discovered an airport game more suited to my skill level and temperament. So while my wife fills in the Sudoku squares at the airport lounge, I fire up the laptop to play a free online flash game called Airport Security.
Airport Security is made by a company called Persuasive Games, which claims its games are intended for ''persuasion, instruction and activism.'' It can be found at persuasivegames.com.

Drew Lanning, a San Francisco gamer (drewlanning.com), describes Airport Security as a ''fast-paced and thoughtful flash game'' in which ''you play the role of an airport security agent screening passengers.''

As little animated passengers march up to the checkpoint, you must click on icons of various prohibited items depicted in their carry-on bags or on their persons, while not letting the lines back up. (A laptop without a mouse is not advisable).

The trick is, news flashes on the bottom of the screen keep changing the rules on what's allowed and what's not. You have to be quick to click on newly prohibited or allowable items, among them Sioux war bonnets, tubes of Preparation H, cattle skulls and conch shells.

The voice announcements are also maddening and distracting, just like real airports. ''Attention all passengers: Please be advised that transporting any object through security is discouraged,'' one says. ''Mr. John Smith, please pick up your underpants at the west security booth,'' says another.
There are three skill levels: fickle, arbitrary and knee-jerk.

Online reviews of the game are, let's say, mixed. ''It's kinda stupid,'' writes one critic. ''It's the best game in the world!'' raves another. I'll just say it's somewhat stupid, and requires fast reflexes and an ability to adapt to absurd and arbitrary rules changes.
Just like real airport security.

That's the general idea, said Ian Bogost, an assistant professor of video game criticism and video game rhetoric (bet you didn't know there was such a discipline) at the Georgia Institute of Technology and a founding partner of Persuasive Games, which is based in Atlanta. Persuasive Games makes serious video games that require time and skill. But the Airport Security game is a fast diversion with a point, Mr. Bogost said. ''It's a kind of game we call news games,'' he said. ''They're really like a video game equivalent of an editorial cartoon. They're small scale, in-and-out quick games, like little editorials on current events.''

Airport Security was designed within weeks after those bewildering and frequently changing rules banning liquids, gels and other substances from carry-on bags were introduced last August. ''It came out of a desire to demonstrate the absurdity of these arbitrary changes that appear to have nothing to do with actual security and everything to do with what people call security theater,'' he said.

''We try to understand video games as a medium capable of a whole range of expressions beyond simply entertainment, from the point of view of criticism rather than distraction,'' Mr. Bogost said, adding: ''Games can make arguments and change opinions, not only through satire but also through the analytical process. In some games we designed for workers in public policy, we simulate the interactions between policy and daily life.''

So Airport Security, simple as it is, is meant to be more than a joke, he said. ''You have a source system that's really complicated like airport security and you don't have to dumb down the issues involved.''
He added that in games ''we can represent the complexities and interrelations between issues in a much more sophisticated way than, say, if we talk about them in two-minute sound bites on TV.''

It all made sense to me. Right after our phone conversation, I rushed back to play Airport Security, but my skill level had already slipped badly. It seems I let passengers carry too much contraband, like an ice cream sundae and a rattlesnake.
My score: zero. A sad little trumpet wah-wah sound let me know the bad guys had won.
